section.title: Installation
section.para: Unpack the downloaded .tar.gz file and enter the libfeide/src directory. Here you will find the source code for all the components needed for the library except for SSL, which needs to be dynamically linked. Before compiling you might want to edit the Makefile in this directory to fit the machine you are running (currently it compiles with -DLINUX and -DWITHOPENSSL, which perhaps should be changed).
Running make libfeide.a will create the library you need for linking FEIDE functionality into your applications. You might want to copy it into /usr/local/lib or a similar directory.

section.title: Data structures
section.para: The library defines three structures, two of them are connected to the get_attributes function.

section.title: f_config
section.para: This structure contains "session" information for the library. It is used to set HTTP Basic Authentication information, the target URL for authentication, whether to enable Single Sign-On (SSO) and to fetch the error string from the lower gSOAP library.

section.title: f_attr and f_attr_array
section.para: These structures are interconnected and both only used with get_attributes. f_attr_array is a container structure for a "dynamic" array of f_attr objects.

section.title: Description
section.para: f_init fills the f_config structure with its needed memeber variables. url is the URL for the Moria authentication service. userid is the username for the HTTP Basic Authentication (if any) on the server hosting the Moria service. passwd is the password for the same authentication mechanism. sso is a "boolean" to say whether the client library should attempt to use Single Sign-On with the server.

section.title: Return value
section.para: Returns a pointer to a f_config structure that is set with the arguments given to the function. If there is no memory available to allocate for the structure it will return NULL.

section.title: Description
section.para: When a user requests a resource with access limited by Moria, this will request Moria for a URL that it can redirect the user to for authentication. config is a pointer to a structure initialised with f_init. attributes is a NULL-terminated array of character strings that contains the different attributes the client would like to receive about the user after he is authenticated. uprefix and upostfix together with the session key from Moria makes the URL the user will be redirected to by Moria after authentication. url is the pointer to a character pointer that will point to the URL with which to redirect after successful execution.

section.title: Return value
section.para: F_SESSION_OK if everything went well, and url pointer was filled with the URL. F_SESSION_DENIED signals that we were not accepted to the server because of failed HTTP Basic Authentication. F_SESSION_CERROR signals that there was some sort of client-side error. F_SESSION_SERROR tells us that the server signalled some sort of error. In all error scenarios the error_str of the config structure will be set.

section.title: Description
section.para: When the use returns after authentication, he will carry a ticket from Moria which can be used with this function to get the attributes requested with f_request_session. config is a pointer to the structure initialised with f_init. id a string containing the ticket the user has from Moria. attributes will be a container to the data if running the function was successful.

section.title: Return value
section.para: It will return F_ATTR_OK if everything went as it should. F_ATTR_DENIED is when we were denied the information we wanted. F_ATTR_ERROR when an error occurred. In all cases error_str can be viewed just as with f_request_session.

section.para: Frees the memory allocated to fill the f_attr_array pointers from f_get_attributes.
